column4: in linux, are there any applications available which install a software for you? (like windows installer in windows)      (apart from Synaptic packet manager or apt or aptitude)
synaptic is apt, and apt is your manager

ok, there are a lot of packages which are not available in the repositories, so if i download their source code from the net, are there any applications which would give me a GUI to install the software?
you just compile and run
but see if you can find a .deb package, it's usually better

yes i just have to compile and run, but is there any application availabe which would let me just click on a button and do it? for example in windows, you just have to click on the install icon and it does the rest for you
no
on windows you're not compiling from source
that's what a debian package would be, more or less
you install it using dpkg -i package.deb
right, you don't get the source, but then what does the install do in windows?
installs the binary
and messes with registry
but you dont really need to "install" anything
usually you put those programs on /var/opt/

i was thinking of a project idea for the summers, and i started thinking about why people in general don't use linux. they don't want to type in commands, so if there is some GUI for that as well, then it would be useful
that's what synaptic is about. but once you leave the repositories, you're on your own
and really, the console is your friend
you'll get used to it
yes, but can something be built which would make it easier for the not-so-familiar-console guy to install applications not availabe in the repositories?
yes, you build a deb package for that specific app
and if it's useful it could be integrated to the repository
